description: The noun is derived from Old English wana (“defect, shortage”); the verb from Old English wanian via Middle English wanien. Both ultimately trace to Proto-West Germanic *wanōn, from Proto-Germanic *wanōną, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁weh₂- (“to leave, abandon; empty, deserted”).

entries.meaning: A gradual diminution in power, value, intensity etc.
examples: In the morning, one might say, his face was of a fine florid hue, but after twelve o'clock, meridian -- his dinner hour -- it blazed like a grate full of Christmas coals; and continued blazing -- but, as it were, with a gradual wane -- till six o'clock, PM, or thereabouts; after which, I saw no more of the proprietor of the face, [...].

entries.meaning: The lunar phase during which the sun seems to illuminate less of the moon as its sunlit area becomes progressively smaller as visible from Earth.
examples: It was very dark, for although the sky was clear the moon was now well in the wane, and would not rise till the small hours.
The situation of the Venetian party in the wane of the eighteenth century had become extremely critical.

entries.meaning: (woodworking) A rounded corner caused by lack of wood, often showing bark.
examples: Sapwood, or even bark, may appear on the corners, or may have been cut off, resulting in wane, or missing timber.

verbs.description: wane (third-person singular simple present wanes, present participle waning, simple past and past participle waned)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To progressively lose its splendor, value, ardor, power, intensity etc.; to decline.
examples: Land and trade ever will wax and wane together.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Said of light that dims or diminishes in strength.
examples: The skies may hold not the splendour of sundown fast; / It wanes into twilight as dawn dies down into day.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, astronomy) Said of the Moon as it passes through the phases of its monthly cycle where its surface is less and less visible.
examples: The fall of Jack, and the subsequent fall of Jill, simply represent the vanishing of one moon-spot after another, as the moon wanes.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Said of a time period that comes to an end.
examples: Fast as autumn days toward winter: yet it seems//Here that autumn wanes not, here that woods and streams

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To decrease physically in size, amount, numbers or surface.

examples: In which no lustful finger can profane him, Nor any earth with black eclipses wane him

description: From Middle English wōne, wāne (“dwelling," "custom”), of unclear origins, compare wont.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Northern England and Scotland, obsolete) A house or dwelling.
